trans-unit.source: How to use blob storage (C++) | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: How to use blob storage (C++) | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use the blob storage service in Azure. Samples are written in C++.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use the blob storage service in Azure. Samples are written in C++.

trans-unit.source: This guide will demonstrate how to perform common scenarios using the Azure Blob storage service.
trans-unit.target: This guide will demonstrate how to perform common scenarios using the Azure Blob storage service.

trans-unit.source: The samples are written in C++ and use the <linkText>Azure Storage Client Library for C++</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: The samples are written in C++ and use the <linkText>Azure Storage Client Library for C++</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The scenarios covered include uploading, listing, downloading, and deleting blobs.
trans-unit.target: The scenarios covered include uploading, listing, downloading, and deleting blobs.

trans-unit.source: This guide targets the Azure Storage Client Library for C++ version 1.0.0 and above.
trans-unit.target: This guide targets the Azure Storage Client Library for C++ version 1.0.0 and above.

trans-unit.source: The recommended version is Storage Client Library 1.0.0, which is available via <linkText>NuGet</linkText><title></title> or <linkText>GitHub</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: The recommended version is Storage Client Library 1.0.0, which is available via <linkText>NuGet</linkText><title></title> or <linkText>GitHub</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: In this guide, you will use storage features which can be run within a C++ application.
trans-unit.target: In this guide, you will use storage features which can be run within a C++ application.

trans-unit.source: To do so, you will need to install the Azure Storage Client Library for C++ and create an Azure storage account in your Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: To do so, you will need to install the Azure Storage Client Library for C++ and create an Azure storage account in your Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: To install the Azure Storage Client Library for C++, you can use the following methods:
trans-unit.target: To install the Azure Storage Client Library for C++, you can use the following methods:

trans-unit.source: Linux: Follow the instructions given in the Azure Storage Client Library for C++ README page.
trans-unit.target: Linux: Follow the instructions given in the Azure Storage Client Library for C++ README page.

trans-unit.source: Windows: In Visual Studio, click Tools > NuGet Package Manager > Package Manager Console.
trans-unit.target: Windows: In Visual Studio, click Tools > NuGet Package Manager > Package Manager Console.

trans-unit.source: Type the following command into the NuGet Package Manager console and press ENTER.
trans-unit.target: Type the following command into the NuGet Package Manager console and press ENTER.

trans-unit.source: Add the following include statements to the top of the C++ file where you want to use the Azure storage APIs to access blobs:
trans-unit.target: Add the following include statements to the top of the C++ file where you want to use the Azure storage APIs to access blobs:

trans-unit.source: An Azure storage client uses a storage connection string to store endpoints and credentials for accessing data management services.
trans-unit.target: An Azure storage client uses a storage connection string to store endpoints and credentials for accessing data management services.

trans-unit.source: When running in a client application, you must provide the storage connection string in the following format, using the name of your storage account and the storage access key for the storage account listed in the Management Portal for the AccountName and AccountKey values.
trans-unit.target: When running in a client application, you must provide the storage connection string in the following format, using the name of your storage account and the storage access key for the storage account listed in the Management Portal for the AccountName and AccountKey values.

trans-unit.source: For information on storage accounts and access keys, see <linkText>About Azure Storage Accounts</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For information on storage accounts and access keys, see <linkText>About Azure Storage Accounts</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: This example shows how you can declare a static field to hold the connection string:
trans-unit.target: This example shows how you can declare a static field to hold the connection string:

trans-unit.source: To test your application in your local Windows computer, you can use the Microsoft Azure <linkText>storage emulator</linkText><title></title> that is installed with the <linkText>Azure SDK</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: To test your application in your local Windows computer, you can use the Microsoft Azure <linkText>storage emulator</linkText><title></title> that is installed with the <linkText>Azure SDK</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The storage emulator is a utility that simulates the Blob, Queue, and Table services available in Azure on your local development machine.
trans-unit.target: The storage emulator is a utility that simulates the Blob, Queue, and Table services available in Azure on your local development machine.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows how you can declare a static field to hold the connection string to your local storage emulator:
trans-unit.target: The following example shows how you can declare a static field to hold the connection string to your local storage emulator:

trans-unit.source: To start the Azure storage emulator, Select the Start button or press the Windows key.
trans-unit.target: To start the Azure storage emulator, Select the Start button or press the Windows key.

trans-unit.source: Begin typing Azure Storage Emulator, and select Microsoft Azure Storage Emulator from the list of applications.
trans-unit.target: Begin typing Azure Storage Emulator, and select Microsoft Azure Storage Emulator from the list of applications.

trans-unit.source: The following samples assume that you have used one of these two methods to get the storage connection string.
trans-unit.target: The following samples assume that you have used one of these two methods to get the storage connection string.

trans-unit.source: You can use the cloud_storage_account class to represent your Storage Account information.
trans-unit.target: You can use the cloud_storage_account class to represent your Storage Account information.

trans-unit.source: To retrieve your storage account information from the storage connection string, you can use the parse method.
trans-unit.target: To retrieve your storage account information from the storage connection string, you can use the parse method.

trans-unit.source: Next, get a reference to a cloud_blob_client class as it allows you to retrieve objects that represent containers and blobs stored within the Blob Storage Service.
trans-unit.target: Next, get a reference to a cloud_blob_client class as it allows you to retrieve objects that represent containers and blobs stored within the Blob Storage Service.

trans-unit.source: The following code creates a cloud_blob_client object using the storage account object we retrieved above:
trans-unit.target: The following code creates a cloud_blob_client object using the storage account object we retrieved above:

trans-unit.source: This example shows how to create a container if it does not already exist:
trans-unit.target: This example shows how to create a container if it does not already exist:

trans-unit.source: By default, the new container is private and you must specify your storage access key to download blobs from this container.
trans-unit.target: By default, the new container is private and you must specify your storage access key to download blobs from this container.

trans-unit.source: If you want to make the files (blobs) within the container available to everyone, you can set the container to be public using the following code:
trans-unit.target: If you want to make the files (blobs) within the container available to everyone, you can set the container to be public using the following code:

trans-unit.source: Anyone on the Internet can see blobs in a public container, but you can modify or delete them only if you have the appropriate access key.
trans-unit.target: Anyone on the Internet can see blobs in a public container, but you can modify or delete them only if you have the appropriate access key.

trans-unit.source: Azure Blob Storage supports block blobs and page blobs.
trans-unit.target: Azure Blob Storage supports block blobs and page blobs.

trans-unit.source: In the majority of cases, block blob is the recommended type to use.
trans-unit.target: In the majority of cases, block blob is the recommended type to use.

trans-unit.source: To upload a file to a block blob, get a container reference and use it to get a block blob reference.
trans-unit.target: To upload a file to a block blob, get a container reference and use it to get a block blob reference.

trans-unit.source: Once you have a blob reference, you can upload any stream of data to it by calling the upload_from_stream method.
trans-unit.target: Once you have a blob reference, you can upload any stream of data to it by calling the upload_from_stream method.

trans-unit.source: This operation will create the blob if it didn't previously exist, or overwrite it if it does exist.
trans-unit.target: This operation will create the blob if it didn't previously exist, or overwrite it if it does exist.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows how to upload a blob into a container and assumes that the container was already created.
trans-unit.target: The following example shows how to upload a blob into a container and assumes that the container was already created.

trans-unit.source: Alternatively, you can use the upload_from_file method to upload a file to a block blob.
trans-unit.target: Alternatively, you can use the upload_from_file method to upload a file to a block blob.

trans-unit.source: To list the blobs in a container, first get a container reference.
trans-unit.target: To list the blobs in a container, first get a container reference.

trans-unit.source: You can then use the container's list_blobs method to retrieve the blobs and/or directories within it.
trans-unit.target: You can then use the container's list_blobs method to retrieve the blobs and/or directories within it.

trans-unit.source: To access the rich set of properties and methods for a returned list_blob_item, you must call the list_blob_item.as_blob method to get a cloud_blob object, or the list_blob.as_directory method to get a cloudblobdirectory object.
trans-unit.target: To access the rich set of properties and methods for a returned list_blob_item, you must call the list_blob_item.as_blob method to get a cloud_blob object, or the list_blob.as_directory method to get a cloudblobdirectory object.

trans-unit.source: The following code demonstrates how to retrieve and output the URI of each item in the my-sample-container container:
trans-unit.target: The following code demonstrates how to retrieve and output the URI of each item in the my-sample-container container:

trans-unit.source: For more details on listing operations, see <linkText>List Azure Storage Resources in C++</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more details on listing operations, see <linkText>List Azure Storage Resources in C++</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: To download blobs, first retrieve a blob reference and then call the download_to_stream method.
trans-unit.target: To download blobs, first retrieve a blob reference and then call the download_to_stream method.

trans-unit.source: The following example uses the download_to_stream method to transfer the blob contents to a stream object that you can then persist to a local file.
trans-unit.target: The following example uses the download_to_stream method to transfer the blob contents to a stream object that you can then persist to a local file.

trans-unit.source: Alternatively, you can use the download_to_file method to download the contents of a blob to a file.
trans-unit.target: Alternatively, you can use the download_to_file method to download the contents of a blob to a file.

trans-unit.source: In addition, you can also use the download_text method to download the contents of a blob as a text string.
trans-unit.target: In addition, you can also use the download_text method to download the contents of a blob as a text string.

trans-unit.source: To delete a blob, first get a blob reference and then call the delete_blob method on it.
trans-unit.target: To delete a blob, first get a blob reference and then call the delete_blob method on it.

trans-unit.source: Now that you've learned the basics of blob storage, follow these links to learn more about Azure Storage.
trans-unit.target: Now that you've learned the basics of blob storage, follow these links to learn more about Azure Storage.
